talk.author: did:plc:b62owfzpn4uch4wqu4vd5c4o
talk.utter: It’s worth noting that Bluesky is organized as a PBC, which means that while they are for-profit, they do not have an obligation to maximize shareholder value if it conflicts with the public interest.

talk.author: did:plc:icvvkdp73dg7cvqrvkwjmche
talk.utter: If you happen to know this: is a PBC the same thing as what we call a bcorp in the UK? Interesting to read your input here.

talk.author: did:plc:b62owfzpn4uch4wqu4vd5c4o
talk.utter: PBC is a very nebulous designation right now. In many cases they’re little more than a notice to investors not to expect ruthless profit maximization at all costs. There’s no specific third-party auditing them like there is with B Corps, PBCs largely define their own standard to be held to, if any.

talk.author: did:plc:e2dza2nakupo2gz24ddtf625
talk.utter: Appreciate it! Am thinking about all kinds of business and service models (and combinations of them). Including co-ops, time banking, and other ways to create shared value. Connecting with other and having a think together. :)

talk.author: did:plc:b62owfzpn4uch4wqu4vd5c4o
talk.utter: Worthwhile things to think about! While I think Bluesky’s model beats the industry standard, nothing beats true worker ownership. Ultimately the only people who really have a company’s best interests at heart are the people doing the actual work—no owner no matter how benevolent can replace that.
